title: Projects
text:
This project was able to fill the identified research gap 
Introduced a novel algorithm to forecast the price direction based on clustering and classification techniques. 
Rewarded with a grade of A (Grade point: 4.00 out of 4.00 scale) at the final evaluation. 
Won a merit award from the undergraduate category of the Best Research Awards 2023, organized by the Institute of Applied Statistics Sri Lanka (IASSL). 
Published as an article in the Sri Lanka Journal of Applied Statistics (SLJAS), Volume 25 Issue 1.

title: Projects
text:
Academic Projects

DSjobtracker







This project is about data science jobs. The R flexdashboard was created using the data collected from data science job advertisements. This dashboard provides an idea about the job fields, job requirements, expected education qualifications, skills and experience. This project was done as a group work, under the guidance of Dr. Thiyanga Talagala  who is a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Statistics, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura.  Dashboard | CRAN R Package | Code | Video on how the dashboard works






Time table dashboard for FAS, USJ







This project is about visualizing the time table of the Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura. The R shiny dashboard was created using the data collected from time tables. This dashboard provides an idea about the overview of the faculty time table, course view, lecturer view and lecture hall view. This project was done as a group work, under the guidance of Dr. Thiyanga Talagala  who is a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Statistics, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura.  Code | Video on how the dashboard works






Tea Export Revenue Forecasting and Analyzing the Impact of COVID-19







This project is about modelling and forecasting the tea export revenue in Sri Lanka. The data set was collected from the Central Bank of Sri Lanka. The impact of COVID-19 on Sri Lankan tea export revenue was assessed. Time series analysis was done under two approaches and a SARIMA model was used to generate forecasts.  Code






Myth analysis about mosquito bites and HIV/AIDS







This project investigated how the knowledge regarding the myth of HIV/AIDS, “People can get HIV virus from mosquito bites” varies on ever married women’s socio and demographic characteristics. This study is based on Sri Lanka Demographic and Health survey (DHS) in 2016 conducted by the Department of Census and Statistics (DCS). A logistic regression model was fitted based on the analysis.  Code

title: Projects
section: The History of the War of the Ring
text:
The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth’s history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

title: Projects
text:
Collaborative Projects

SBPTD project was done with the Ministry of Education, Sri Lanka. A program was implemented by the Ministry in order to improve the teachers’ teaching and students’ learning. Data collection was done from a sample of schools. I was responsible in data entry and data analysis for this project.

title: Experience
text:
Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura



AMT 325 2.0 Regression Analysis | Course Outline








An Applied Mathematics course for third year students focused on regression analysis and its applications. The course introduced simple linear regression with parameter estimation, interpretation of coefficients, properties of least squares estimators, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, predictions, and measuring the quality of fit. Students also explored model adequacy checking through residual analysis. Topics in multiple linear regression included matrix notations, parameter estimation, multicollinearity and qualitative predictors. Practical applications were demonstrated using R programming, and statistical packages such as Minitab and SPSS.





AMT 377 2.0 Computational Statistics | Course Outline








An Applied Mathematics course for third year students focused on statistical computing and data analysis using R. Students were introduced to R objects, their modes and attributes, including vectors, matrices, lists, data frames, and factors, as well as techniques for data input and output, descriptive statistics, and graphical representation. The course also explored generating data from probability distributions, logical operations, control structures, and working with R packages. Core topics included hypothesis testing with parametric and non-parametric methods, confidence intervals, linear models, simulation studies, and developing custom functions to solve applied problems.





MAN 128 1.0 Introduction to Statistics | Course Outline








A Management Science course for first year students focused on statistical techniques and their practical applications in everyday life. The course emphasized identifying and defining variables in real world problems, along with the basics of survey planning and data collection. Students learnt decision making through descriptive statistics and were introduced to probability theory, including probability rules, conditional probability, interpretation, and Bayes’ Theorem. Random variables, probability mass and density functions, cumulative distribution functions, key distributions such as Binomial, Poisson, Uniform, and Normal, and sampling methods were discussed.








AMT 112 2.0 Mathematical Statistics I | Course Outline








An Applied Mathematics course for first year students focused on the fundamentals of statistics and probability. The syllabus covered topics such as probability rules, interpretation, classical and empirical probability, conditional probability, independence, and Bayes’ Theorem. Students also studied random variables, probability mass and density functions, cumulative distribution functions, moment generating functions, and descriptive measures such as mean and variance. Key probability distributions including Binomial, Poisson, Uniform, and Normal were introduced, along with transformations of random variables, sampling distributions, and the Central Limit Theorem.





AMT 212 2.0 Mathematical Statistics II | Course Outline








An Applied Mathematics course for second year students focused on estimation, hypothesis testing, and non-parametric methods. Estimation topics included method of moments, maximum likelihood, evaluation of estimators, and interval estimation using pivotal quantities. In parametric testing, students learnt one sample and two sample tests for means, variances, and proportions. Non-parametric methods covered one sample tests, two independent and dependent sample tests, and K independent and dependent sample tests. The course also addressed correlation testing, Type I & II errors, significance levels, and test power, providing an understanding of statistical inference.





MAN 103 1.0 Methods of Operational Research | Course Outline








A Management Science course for first year students focused on the fundamentals of operations research. The course introduced terminology, phases, and methods of operations research, followed by linear programming concepts. Students learnt graphical methods and Simplex method, covering standard form, slack and surplus variables, artificial variables, maximization and minimization problems, and special cases. Topics also included duality theory, sensitivity analysis, and transportation models.








Co-supervised final year undergraduate research projects of the BSc (Honours) in Applied Sciences (Applied Mathematics) titled “Predicting the Impact of Tunnel Excavation on Groundwater Levels in Wells - A Machine Learning Approach”
Providing statistical guidance for the final year undergraduate research and industry collaboration projects.

title: Teaching
text:
arXiv Preprint | Code
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

title: Projects
text:
Statistical Consultancy Projects

The client who was pursuing the MPhil needed to identify the plant assemblage in the wetland and its relationship with water quality and soil quality. One way ANOVA models were used to find the effect of vegetation type on each water quality parameter. Next the MANOVA model was used to find the effect of vegetation type on water quality and soil quality parameters collectively. Finally, the tukey test was used to find the significantly different vegetation types for each variable. A report containing the methodology, outputs and interpretations was delivered.
The client wanted to determine the characterization of phytochemical composition, antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties of aerial roots of Ficus benghalensis. Statistical analysis was done and a report containing the methodology, outputs and interpretations was delivered.
The client from the Department of Mathematics mainly expected to analyze the final grade against attendance in the MAT 211 1.0 Linear Algebra II course unit. They provided the mid exam marks, final exam marks and attendance of the students. Exploratory data analysis and creation of a dashboard was done and delivered to the client.
The project from a postgraduate client. The purpose was to visualize the Dengue hotspots and maps from the provided shapefiles. The initial dengue hotspot visualization and a report for Dengue hotspot Visualization were created. Provided guidelines to be followed when shapefiles with matching coordinate systems are available and provided a reusable code to be used in the analysis.
The project submitted by a client from the Department of Food Science and Technology, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura. Consulted the client on the descriptive analysis of data, data modeling and model fitting and interpretation of the statistical outputs. Created and delivered an R function for the needed statistical data analysis. Providing interpretations for the outputs taken and delivered to the client along with the reasons.

The audience was the workers who don’t have a statistics knowledge and the purpose of this workshop was to provide an idea about the importance of using statistical techniques to solve business problems.

title: Experience
text:
Visiting Lecturer (November 2024 - Present)
Institute of Applied Statistics Sri Lanka (IASSL)

Certificate in Applied Statistics

CAS 105 1.0 Introduction to Statistical Modeling

Introduction to Statistical Modelling course introduced students to the fundamental concepts, principles, and techniques of statistical modelling. The course covered key topics such as correlation and simple linear regression, highlighting their applications in analyzing relationships between variables. Emphasis was placed on developing a strong foundation in modelling approaches while enhancing analytical and problem solving skills. By combining theory with practical applications, the course prepared students to apply statistical modelling techniques effectively in real world contexts.


Research Project Supervision

Supervised a Higher Diploma in Applied Statistics research projects titled “Predictive Model to Forecast Detection Probability: A Study in Air Surveillance Radars”

title: Experience
text:
Statistical Consultant (January 2023 - April 2024)
Department of Statistics, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura

Statistical Consultancy Service

The client who was pursuing the MPhil needed to identify the plant assemblage in the wetland and its relationship with water quality and soil quality. One way ANOVA models were used to find the effect of vegetation type on each water quality parameter. Next the MANOVA model was used to find the effect of vegetation type on water quality and soil quality parameters collectively. Finally, the tukey test was used to find the significantly different vegetation types for each variable. A report containing the methodology, outputs and interpretations was delivered.
The client wanted to determine the characterization of phytochemical composition, antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties of aerial roots of Ficus benghalensis. Statistical analysis was done and a report containing the methodology, outputs and interpretations was delivered.
The client from the Department of Mathematics mainly expected to analyze the final grade against attendance in the MAT 211 1.0 Linear Algebra II course unit. They provided the mid exam marks, final exam marks and attendance of the students. Exploratory data analysis and creation of a dashboard was done and delivered to the client.
The project from a postgraduate client. The purpose was to visualize the Dengue hotspots and maps from the provided shapefiles. The initial dengue hotspot visualization and a report for Dengue hotspot Visualization were created. Provided guidelines to be followed when shapefiles with matching coordinate systems are available and provided a reusable code to be used in the analysis.
The project submitted by a client from the Department of Food Science and Technology, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura. Consulted the client on the descriptive analysis of data, data modeling and model fitting and interpretation of the statistical outputs. Created and delivered an R function for the needed statistical data analysis. Providing interpretations for the outputs taken and delivered to the client along with the reasons.

title: Hello and welcome to my website!
section: I am Menasha Senanayaka, who is passionate in research and eager to use statistical methods to solve problems. A hard-working, responsible, adaptable, and fast-learning individual who has specialised statistics. Keen in searching for new concepts in the field of statistics. Interested in statistics and data science. I am looking forward for my higher studies journey.

title: Projects
text:
Interactive Tools

StudentMarkAnalyser: Students’ Exam Mark Analysing App







A shiny app to input marks of an examination and obtain the analysis. Anyone needing to conduct an analysis from a mark sheet using an interactive tool can take advantage of this shiny app. Even the users who are not familiar with obtaining statistical outputs from software can take the maximum benefit from this user friendly interactive tool.  Shiny App | Code






Forecaster: Time Series Forecasting App







This app was created with the purpose of using a time series dataset, fitting the appropriate model and generating forecasts. The users can input a univariate time series dataset or a multivariate time series dataset in the ascending order of date. The app is designed to optimize parameters and fit the most appropriate model.  Shiny App | Code
